												I made a review before this a few days into early access, and if you want a TL;DR I'll paraphrase one of my previous lines - buy into it if you're fine with being an alpha tester. I am. It's flawed, but fun.So as Robot Arena III rolls into a full release, it must be considered that the devs themselves say that it's more of a tactical move to bring it out of early access, what with the Steam summer sale approaching fast. But I'm not here to knock their sales strategy.Having a binary recommendation option is tough for some games; this is one of them. To recommend it right this moment as a full release title would be to grossly overrate it's current quality and depth of content. The physics aren't all there as a simulation game, with bad collision physics in certain circumstances and with certain components. Components can still be placed anywhere without any boundaries. The career mode does not reset when all of the tournaments have been finished. There's a bug where the camera won't stop moving up or down in the bot lab after battling some AI opponents that should have been swatted by now.But to not recommend it would be to downplay the monumental effort the devs have been undertaking in the last 4 weeks to improve the game. The first day of early access the game was considered 'full', and it was a mess. You couldn't even build a wedge shaped robot because every robot had box collisions. Now you can. The biggest drive motors would make your robot flip on the spot like one of those toy backflipping dogs unless it weighed as much as a star. Now they don't. Weight classes are back. Should all of these things been in the game on day 1? Absolutely. But they also could have just dumped the game there and then and moved on. They haven't. I respect that.They have good ideas. The 5 layer chassis system is great for rounded shapes or crafting detail. Being able to move components after placing them is one of the best quality of life improvements they could have made after RA2. Someone on Gametechmods[www.gametechmods.com] figured out how to mod the game, even if it's crude at the moment, so a modding community is imminent. Robot Arena III will be great. It's just not 'great' this second.

												I really didn't want to write this review. I'd been one of the more vocal people in the discussions, offering advice on bugs that needed fixing, as well as features I feel should be added/restored. I even emailed these directly to the dev team's preferred email address. I've been tough on the game, but I always hoped that the developers would prove me wrong, that they would update this game into something that humiliates Robot Arena 2.But they instead released it out of Early Access in a buggy, unfinished state and we're approaching two months of not hearing a word from them, unless they are secretly building a big update I feel its safe to say the game is dead.Lets go over just some of the issues.Firstly, the physics are broken. Robot Arena 2 could have issues sometimes but firstly the game is 13 years old, and secondly they weren't as bad at this 2016 release. There was many a time when I would see robots take off seemingly into orbit from the smallest tap.Secondly the glitches are everywhere. Bot building is broken, I don't have to have parts connect to anything and they will still work fine. I can have parts clipping into each other and the game sees no problem with this. When I play Robot Arena 2 they wouldn't let this happen.Robot Arena 2 also wouldn't let me break the career mode, in Robot Arena 3 when it updated a robot that I had built was set to the U class, I cant edit the bot to change it and the tournaments it was in are now impossible to finish. I also found out after deleting a different robot that that one was in a tournament, making that one impossible to finish. Robot Arena 2 has a weight limit and doesn't let you delete robots that are in a tournament in career mode. Robot Arena 2 is 13 years older.The game is way too loud, and the sound is overall a mess. No matter what I do to tinker with the sound it remains for me at the sound level of a Freddy Fazbear jump scare. Plus the game cant handle many sounds at once, I've had many times where because a lot was happening the music would cut out.There is no weight to any attacks in this game, in Robot Arena 2 if I smash a battle axe down onto an opponent, it hits hard. It feels satisfying to destroy opponents that way, but in Robot Arena 3 the hits are far less satisfying, and weapons seem to snap off if you so much as breathe next to them.The only thing I can truly say Robot Arena 3 has over Robot Arena 2 is in the customisation, and even then I'd recommend getting a modded copy of Robot Arena 2 for more tools to play with. They've had a lot of work put into them, and help to keep a 13 year old game fresh even today. (There is even an ongoing mod called the official robot wars mod, its worth checking out!). Also Robot Arena 3 does look better, but I would be disgusted if it didnt look better visually.All in all, just look for a free download of Robot Arena 2, instead of paying £15 for this game. Its nowhere near finished and it likely never will be finished which is probably the most insulting thing, as they deemed this ready for a full release and took it out of early access. If things turn around I will update this review, but I'm not holding out for much hope.

								I am a huge fan of Robot Arena 2. when i saw for the first time RA3 on Steam, I wasn\'t scared by the negative reviews. I was sure that, yes, the game needed some work, but i was also convinced that the game was really fun....I was incredibly wrong.I know, I know, the game is still in early access, but there are a lot of basics problems that not only need to be solved, but changed.Starting to the bot lab. Ok, now you really have the complete possibility to create any, ANY shape for the robots, but the price to pay is too high. The way you modify the chassis is really too difficult. I had trouble even with simple robot desings, the multiple layers scheme is far from being clear. But there is more...Mounting the parts can be really frustrating. The process is really slow, I don\'t get why the parts must to be mounted in a \"standard\" position UNDER the chassis, and then, repositioned where we want. But i like the idea of moving mounted parts, this really is an useful thing. I do not like the way you wire the motors/pistons in RA3. it works in the opposite way of RA2, I found it too messy. But maybe it\'s just me. Ok, time to try our new, fresh built robot, right?....Right?No. For no reason, the physics of the game decided to punch herself with all of his might, resulting in a complete DISASTER.Without touching any key, my robot started to bounce illogically all along the arena. Any attempt to stop it was useless.I\'ve tried to add weight, add more wheels, everything. But no, nothing changed. The only thing i could do was delete the bot and build a new one. In the nex time i\'ve tried different things. I\'ve tried to save space putting motors and wheels outside the chassis (mounted properly with extenders), but for no reason the back of the bot started to bounce. Another scrap. I\'ve also found that you can overlap parts. I was able to put 5 batteries in the same place. You can\'t see a thing like that in a 2016 game.Then i\'ve tried to build a robot in the style of \"Chaos 2\": 2 big motors at the FRONT (ztech HP) to avoid wheelies, light and with a short wheelbase: a functional design in RA2 and in the real life. But what happened next got me mad.Not only there is an exaggerated, insane amount of centrifugal force generated by the motors (that also spin at ridiculous low speed, considering that\'s the most powerful motor of the game) but the centrifugal force does not change even when  the motors are spinning at max speed. The result?Trying to go forward, my robot started to continuosly roll over backward. I was crying inside me.Without hope, i built the last robot.  Big, heavy, slow, but functional.Then i\'ve tried to battle. Sad. Really sad. A lot of sounds are missing, visual effects like fire and sparks are exaggerated and badly done. When you hit your opponent, you don\'t fell like you are hitting it, but you fell like you are pushing, or bouncing on it. You don\'t feel that you are damaging it, you don\'t see the deformations on the chassis, you don\'t see and feel nothing. The only thing that remains is a slow, sad, frustrating game.I hope that this can help the developers. In those contitions, i can\'t play the game without getting mad. BUT.I see potential. I think this could be a really funny game in the future, but things need to be changed. I wish good work to the developers. Maybe in a few months i will be back, to see if something changed. Like me, a lot of people care about this game.

								In its current early access state, I can't recommend the game, simply because it's no better, and probably worse than its predecessor, which, due to it being abandonware is totally free. This sounds like a very harsh thing to say, but unfortunately with steam early access, you never really know if the game will ever come out of it.Everything about the game is worse really. The physics on the robots are inconsistent, despite the newer engine. It makes fighting the robots feel a bit off. You might hit a guy with a spinning disc and have him not move, then he might drive into a wall and that'll be a much larger 'impact.' I didn't use a wedge, but I'm told the chassis of the robot actually makes no difference, ie, if you make a wedge you can't get under people. I can't confirm that. The building has been 'simplified' to the point where it trades ease of use for clunkiness. For instance, if you try to add a 'peg board' to the edge of a disc, there's about 15 attach points on one side, and 3 on the other. You have to click change attach point about 15 times, as opposed to just clicking the attach point you want, then on the motor. It's just not streamlined at all, and I can put everything inside eachother. Next, huge lack of parts. The variety dropped pretty hard in general. There isn't enough weapon motors and the best one isn't strong enough. Moving on, lack of part clarity, none of the motors say how much electricity they draw, as far as I can tell. The armor doesn't necessarilly say how effective it is. Is fibreglass going to give me more or less health than carbon fibre? Something about fire resistance? On a side note, the music is annoying, the sound effects are low quality and just sound weird, and some are ripped from the old game. The graphics, while not that important, are pretty awful. Somehow even though the textures are higher quality, they are just worse looking than the old game. It's hard to explain. They just look like typical stock unity textures, it looks odd and cartoony. I'm sure you'll get the same feeling when you look at the screenshots. I think it's to do with the lighting. For me, a robot building/fighting game where the building isn't great and the fighting is plagued by weird physics isn't worth the buy. Wait until full release, then look at the reviews again.

								At the time I'm writing this, it had been released for a couple of hours and I have played it for just under two hours.  And as much as I love the idea of the reboot, it feels dated.  And sluggish.  I just wish there'd be faster motors, real life robots such as England's own Warhead or America's Bite Force, and a way to make your own drive train, so you can legitimately make either a push bot, or a faster spinner for your robot, or a drum weapon.  On top of that, the motors only seem to point forward when you first put them in, making it a real hassle to make the robot move forward properly.  A majority of the robots in the game as well just feel haphazardly put together as well, with blade spam all over them.Pros:+ It's a nostalgic return to the Robot Arena series.+ Arcade like, and super quick loading times+ Axe like weapons feel like they can deliver a punch.Cons: (Oh boy this is going to be long)- Customisation feels rather limited.- No faster motors or powerul motors.- Spinners feel like and look like a wet noodle.- No real life robots in the game right now.- Preset chassis are small and unvaried.- One graphic on a robot replaces all graphics on all robots.  Not sure if a glitch or really poor design.- Making low profile robots makes awful clanking noises.- Graphics on some styles of robot stretches and makes it look ugly as sin.What I would like to see in the future of this game:*FASTER MOTORS: I want to be able to create a hard hitting spinner bot or a robot that uses a drum weapon and still keep its ability to ram into opponents quickly.*REAL ROBOTS: I wish to see robots old and new in the game.  Whether or not this'll happen is something completely different.*ACTUAL STATS ON ROBOT PARTS: One thing I have noticed is there's a lack of info on parts.  If this gets updated I'd be fairly okay with it.*A DRIVE TRAIN SYSTEM: Having a steering column is nice and all but I would love to make a robot that can steer on a six pence without having to fiddle with motor positioning.  On top of that, I'd love to see a choice between either belt or chain drive, for those who wish to make a robot on a tank drive steering system.*DIFFERENT FORMS OF LOCOMOTION: Wheels are cool, but tank tracks, Walking legs, or even a Half track system would be excellent.*WEIGHT CATEGORIES: Right now, all the robot seem to be in the same kind of weight category, which is quite misleading.*MORE ARENAS!!!: Can't stress that enough right now.  Being in a real arena would be fantastic, such as the old Robot Wars arena or the new Battlebots Battle box.Overall, this feels really outdated and in need of some more work, if I'm brutally honest Octopus Tree.  It doesn't feel polished, and it feels a little rushed on top of that.  Unless this game gets a really big update and pretty much changes the game into a much more customisable game that actually feels like I'm making a robot, then I'd say avoid this for now.A really disappointing start for such a promising game!

								TL;DR -Not great, but buy it anyway, and hopefully the devs will get the budget they need to make Robot Arena 4 the way this game should have been made in the first place.---So, the devs only started showing progress on the game about 5 months ago. That is not nearly enough time to put together a solid game of any kind. This game reflects that lack of time and budget they were given.The improvements to the bot lab are awesome. There is so much more freedom in how a robot can be built now. But that is hampered by the lack of any snap points for component placement or rotation. It's impossible to get any component pointed exactly the same way as any other component, or at the same height. Just adding some snap points would make the bot lab nearly perfect.Unfortunately from there, things get bad. Combat is much more like Robot Arena 1 than anything: slow boxes covered in components driving straight at each other. Even though you can flip other robots over, no matter how you build your chassis shape you cannot simply drive under other robots. You mearly bump into them until some physics instability allows you to accidentally end up underneith. Collisions are super simple. Most of the time chassis and components wont be anywhere near each other when their hit boxes collide. No matter how a match is lost, it classifies every losing robot as "immobilized". Sometimes already counted out robots will get counted out a second time. I can barely hear the "announcer" despite volumes being turned up all the way.The menus for some reason are designed as if I'm using an Xbox controller when I only have keyboard and mouse hooked up. It was quite confusing when it said "Press (A) to continue". Some of the menus apparently scroll, although there are no indications of this except for some images being slightly cut off. Click and drag is the way to scroll these menus for some reason.Textures look ok, and polygon counts are high, so no real complaints on the graphics side of things. There are more parts available than in stock Robot Arena 2, so that is an improvement. Background music is uninspiring stock instrumental stuff.If I had to play this on a tablet or something, it would be a mediocre 5/10, but being released through Steam for PC users, this game is currently a 3/10. It should be way better, but for some reason the studio decided to rush it out in only 5-8 months to test the market. Hopefully they both decide to make a Robot Arena 4, and go all out in making it the most realistic simulation of robot combat ever made like we want instead of the arcadey little toy they gave us.

												It's Buggy, the physics freak out fairly consistently, and the community seems to be fully against the developers at this time; So why do I recommend this game?...Because, despite what people will tell you, this game is an improvement on Robot Arena 2: Most people praise it; And it is a fantastic game... With the right Mods... The building was inaccurate, the physics as a whole were worse than RA3, only more stable and not liable to throw you into the ceiling, the components were limited and unvaried; But this could all be solved with Mods.This is a very solid foundation for the game that it should be: And I find it very fun. It is a sandbox, and though parts are broken; The sand is still here. Some of it may be mud painted tan; Some of it may be gravel; But you can still have a ton of fun in this game.Bugs and glitches always turn people away from games like this, and though this game does have game breaking glitches that occur rather frequently under certain circumstances (Spinner weapons and wedges are generally overpowered or broken; Never as they should be. Either you or your opponent will be flung into the ceiling on contact.) But RA2 wasn't without it's glitches, either. They may not have been as game-breaking, but they were still pretty annoying, and above all, repeatable and constant.I personally don't see what others have a problem with. Yes, there are bugs, But yes, the game is still playable. No, the game isn't in Early Access anymore, and you jump to the conclusion that the game is finished?... Abandoned?... If anything, the main reason this game appears abandoned is because the poisonous community behind it! Perhaps if you weren't screaming at the developers, telling them to go kill themselves, maybe they wouldn't have made it appear as though they had listened…I for one stand behind this game entirely. It isn't perfect; But what is? It's a fun game, and worth the price if you can grab it on sale. I am fine with paying full price, seeing as I WILL be playing it fairly frequently.
